title: Self-interest or solidarity
vignette: You have limited time and money. If you devote them to your own career and comfort, you’ll advance quickly; if you share them with community causes, your own progress slows. Which mindset should guide you?

options.text: Put self first; protect your own interests.
Put others first; accept costs for the common good.

title: Benefit of the doubt
vignette: A co-worker’s account of missing funds is plausible but unverified. Treat them as honest until proven otherwise, or assume they might be covering up a theft?

options.text: Presume innocence; risk being deceived.
Presume guilt; protect society from danger.

title: Seeking honour
vignette: An academic wonders whether to run an aggressive publicity campaign to boost personal brand and attract students, or stay modest and let reputation grow naturally.

options.text: Self-promote; influence grows with recognition.
Remain humble; let honour come unsought.

title: Stepping up in a leaderless moment
vignette: During a street accident no by-stander moves to help an injured cyclist. Do you jump in to direct traffic and give aid, accepting personal risk, or stay back like everyone else?

options.text: Intervene; accept personal risk to rescue the situation.
Stay passive; avoid jeopardising yourself.

title: Starting what you can’t finish
vignette: A volunteer project to clean a polluted river will take years and might stall halfway. Do you sign on knowing you may never see the job done, or decline because unfinished efforts feel wasted?

options.text: Begin anyway; partial progress still helps.
Decline; efforts are wasted if completion is unlikely.

title: Supporting an unjust government
vignette: Citizens are asked to include well-wishes for the national leadership—widely viewed as corrupt—in community meetings. Participate to preserve civic stability, or withhold support on moral grounds?

options.text: Support; stable rule prevents anarchy.
Withhold; conscience over conformity.

title: Earning from specialized knowledge
vignette: A meditation teacher with professional credentials must decide whether to charge tuition or teach for free as a service to seekers.

options.text: Yes; labour deserves compensation.
No; teach altruistically as a religious duty.

title: Mine, yours, ours
vignette: A neighbourhood has a tool library but participation is optional. Should residents share their equipment freely or keep ownership strictly individual?

options.text: Share equitably; promote mutual support.
Respect strict ownership; no forced redistribution.

title: Serving for reward or devotion
vignette: An employee volunteers at a charity. Should they act purely out of commitment to the cause, or is it fine to factor in résumé value and tax benefits?

options.text: Act only out of devotion, ignoring reward.
Let reward motivate; self-interest fuels virtue.

title: Hospitality vs. privacy
vignette: A family considers leaving their spare room available to travellers in need, but that would reduce privacy and increase household costs. Open the door or keep the space private?

options.text: Open the house; welcome strangers.
Limit access; protect family privacy.

title: Distancing from a harmful neighbour
vignette: Your next-door neighbour often engages in dishonest schemes. Do you avoid all contact to protect your family, or keep friendly relations hoping your influence inspires change?

options.text: Cut ties; safeguard yourself and family.
Maintain contact; try to improve them.

title: Pursuing peace vs. avoiding conflict
vignette: Two colleagues are locked in a bitter dispute that hurts team morale. Do you step in to mediate—risking backlash—or stay neutral to avoid entanglement?

options.text: Intervene; reconcile the parties.
Stay out; avoid personal risk and resentment.
